3 citations
The rise of graphene
A. K. Geim; K. S. Novoselov
2007

Owing to its unusual electronic spectrum, graphene has led to the emergence of a new paradigm of 'relativistic' condensed-matter physics, where quantum relativistic phenomena, some of which are unobservable in high-energy physics, can now be mimicked and tested in table-top experiments.

This strictly two-dimensional material exhibits exceptionally high crystal and electronic quality, and, despite its short history, has already revealed a cornucopia of new physics and potential applications, which are briefly discussed here.

graphene represents a conceptually new class of materials that are only one atom thick, and, on this basis, offers new inroads into low-dimensional physics that has never ceased to surprise and continues to provide a fertile ground for applications

2 citations
Graphene: carbon in two dimensions
Mikhail I. Katsnelson
2007

This results in the observation of a number of very peculiar electronic properties – from an anomalous quantum Hall effect to the absence of localization – in this, the first two-dimensional material.

It also provides a bridge between condensed matter physics and quantum electrodynamics, and opens new perspectives for carbon-based electronics.

2008

M. S. Dresselhaus & G. Dresselhaus
2009

A recent review article showed that it is common to use alkali metals (such as potassium) for intercalated graphite compounds (IGCs) to improve the in-plane conductivity of graphite.

A significant blocker to the development of practical applications of intercalated graphite is the difficulty in maintaining a stable sample for experimentation

2009

The essential improvement offered by the GW one-particle Schroedinger equation over the Hartree-Fock equation lies in the explicit description of the potential induced by the additional particle

.. a non-self-consistent, low-order (GW) treatment reduces occupied bandwidths by 10–30 % compared to independent-electron theory, self- consistency

A good approximation for is obtained with Hedin's GW approach, using density-functional theory as a zero-order solution. First-principles GW calculations for real systems have been successfully carried out since the 1980s.

Interlayer cohesive energy of graphite from thermal desorption of polyaromatic hydrocarbons
R. Zacharia, H. Ulbricht, T. Herte
2004

The resulting binding energy per carbon atom of the PAH is 52±5 meV and can be identified with the interlayer cohesive energy of graphite. The resulting cleavage energy of graphite is 61±5 meV/atom, which is considerably larger than previously reported experimental values.
